column11: Review Text

Just the location, right on the sea is already captivating. The Fountain of Miracles, as it is also called, is visited almost exclusively by locals, there is a pool for men and one for women. I wasn't in the water, but admired the place dry
Quite surprising this pool of ritual ablutions transformed into a public ‚Äúpool‚Äù. But it‚Äôs interesting in the end.
a little out of the way in Jaffna. was interesting tho. If you make your way to jaffna then you should visit. Jaffna does not have a lot going for it
The only good thing was that there was no entry fee. Otherwise, the toilets were in an unacceptable condition, there were no changing rooms, and plastic waste was floating in the pool.

column8: Discovering the Magic of Keerimalai: An Oasis of Tranquility in the Heart of Sri Lanka
column11: Keerimalai is a breathtakingly beautiful and serene lagoon located on the northern coast of Sri Lanka. It's a natural swimming pool surrounded by lush green hills, crystal clear waters, and an atmosphere that is both peaceful and energizing. Visitors flock to Keerimalai to take a dip in its healing waters, believed to have curative properties, and to bask in the tranquility of this idyllic spot. With its stunning natural beauty, rich history, and spiritual significance, Keerimalai is truly a hidden gem waiting to be discovered.
Quite interesting to note that this pond was a fresh water and one was very close to the sea. Beautiful of the sea and the ancient temple

column8: A mineral water spring  in Jaffna
column11: It is a renowned mineral water spring which is believed to have healing properties.  The spring forms two swimming pools with separate entrances for women and men.
Beautiful place but only for men. The women's tubs are undergoing renovation. It is located inside a Hindu temple. Great atmosphere and great experience. You arrive by local bus from jaffna.
Historical and Natural water flowing pond. Poorly maintained, may be due to the closure of Covid-19. Not recommended if the place is crowded since you can't bathe.

column8: Keerimalai freshwater  Spring pond near the beach
column11: this is a mineral water spring pond. The specialty is it‚Äôs located near to the Sea and still contains freshwater. The history of the pond is bound with the Hindu mythologies.

I saw many of the locals enjoying a nice dip. I heard that this has a lot to do with ancient hindu mythology. it was quite slippery so please do be careful. Water was very cold and perfect for a cold dip during the hot Jaffna weather
Very nice place near naguleshwaram. Nice pond. Like it very much. Normally it cleans water from sea.
Men and women have separate sides...what you see in the pictures is the open to sky mens bath....the womens side is beyond the wall & enclosed Stunning views of the Indian ocean

A pond with natural spring water. It‚Äôs so close to the sea. Hindus believe the water here is sacred such that it has a special healing power. A separate area is there for the ladies to have a bath. Since many people are bathing at a time and the water is still and not flowing we felt it was not so clean to dive down. Parking is available at the main road and you have to walk a small distance to reach here. Washroom facilities available to change your clothes.
It's a nice place by the beach for the local pilgrims to have a good bath. Separate facilities available for male and female pilgrims.
A bathing pond just by the seaside, Keerimalai is a good destination for nature lovers and pilgrims alike!
This famous tank is not maintained, it is dirty. You can visit but it looks dirty to bathe. There is a beautiful kovil close by..
Separate baths for males and females. The males can't even see the female swimmers. Hmm. But lovely nonetheless. Parking not convenient.
Visited these springs to view not really swim. My kids weren‚Äôt keen. The view is amazing overlooking the bay. The water from the pool is suppose to have healing properties.

It's a nice place to see and the surroundings are pretty. Its on a nice beach. The water is not as clean as it used to be, but I'm talking 40 years ago! One of the 5 ancient temple ruins are next door and no one notices it!

The Keeramalai pond, located next to the sea, separated only by the surrounding wall, gets its fresh water from an underground freshwater spring.  I tasted the water and found it slightly salty.  People believe that this freshwater spring is connected through a tunnel to the Nilvarai Bottomless Well located about 10 kilometres away.  There is no charge for bathing in the pond.  However, it costs Rs 30 to use the changing rooms with lockers. Although TripAdvisor lists this as "hot springs", the water is not even warm! I shall submit a modification to this heading to reflect that this is a "fresh water" pond as opposed to "hot"! There are two ponds here, the larger one for males and the smaller one for females.  There are separate changing rooms too for male and female visitors.  Visitors are not permitted to use soap within ponds to prevent pollution. The miraculous powers associated with its waters are believed to cure skin infections and help childless women achieve pregnancy.  Water analysis has confirmed the presence of high mineral content in the waters. There is a large decorated hall in front meant for visitors to rest. According to legend as narrated by our guide, an Indian princess born with a deformed face begot a human pretty face after bathing in this pond! Personally speaking, I refrained from having a bath, as it is to me a public bathing place with no chlorination!  However, there were many people enjoying its waters quite happily!!
A place with good water near beach and temple. A place with really natural pool and good water spending time in it was a glad moment

The pool is segregated into a publically viewable men's pool and a private women's one. Entrance attracts a small charge.  It is fun to have a dip.  But be aware that changing facilities are limited and not very private and the pool's surface covered with algae - so dont swallow the water

I thought it was hot springs but when asked local people about it, they said it is considered as divine water and NOT hot springs. There are two ponds with steps. One is for men and the other is for women. You are not allowed to wear sandals in to the pond and using soap and shampoo is prohibited.On the full moon and first moon days the nearby sea water mix with the fresh water in the pond and it becomes salty. The other days it is filled with fresh water. On the left side corner is the place the fresh water to flow in to the pond. First go to the sea and have some fun over there. (Also you can walk through the small canal to the sea that connects the pond through the water gate.). Then come to the pond and bath. No tickets. If you want to shower in fresh water pay Rs 30 and bath in the reserved place. You can visit the nearby temples.

It‚Äôs a tuktuk ride from Jaffna to see the pools. The men‚Äôs bathing area is open and stepped - like the photos. However, if you‚Äôre a woman you can only bathe in a small, shallow private section surrounded by rough concrete floors and walls. I‚Äôll swim in most places but this didn‚Äôt appeal (there was rubbish in the little pool). Sorry. Looked like it was fun for the guys though!

I opted not to have a dip, I got changed but chose just to dip toe as did not feel comfortable as only person there and did not feel that clean. Partner (male) enjoyed having a swim in pool which public can view
Not a clean place to have a bath. There are two bathing place for male & female.They are separated from see.

I‚Äôm not a huge sigh seeing person, so got dragged into going here. My God, what a breathtaking view. Something special about the geographic location of where it‚Äôs located as well, standing looking over the Indian Ocean, right at the top of Sri Lanka, and then the beautiful waters, fresh air filling the lungs... it was special. Check it out!!
It has been kept very clean and there are separate bathing areas for males and females. We were able to only look around and did not have time for dip.
This does not have a beach.. It is just the hot springs which you can bathe in. The water is warm. You have to park next door and walk over which is just a 2 minute walk.

I loved this place The men‚Äôs pool was not too busy when I visited. Not sure how many tourists visit because there was much hilarity when I entered the pool Great water and not too cold I am sure it helped my sore hamstring I paid 30 R‚Äôs Very clean area
You can bathe in the pool.The sea looks rough .There is a Hindu temple nearby.This is out of the city centre but close to the airport.

We visited the Keerimalai hot springs whilst passing on a scooter from Pedro Point to the Jaffna islands out to the west. Would thoroughly recommend for a brief stop off; there are no tourists only Sri Lankan locals. I went in the male baths and the water was nice, but apparently the female section is nowhere near as clean. Wouldn't recommend getting any of the water in your mouth though; the baths have a reputation of having 'healing properties' so I imagine a lot of sick people frequent them.

These pools close to the Hindu temple, have quite a holiday feel to them as the butt up against the beach, with a pilgrims hostel and facilities close by. There are often busloads of people getting out to go to the temple and many take a stroll down to the beach too, and the men's pool is obviously very popular. Swimwear appears to be long shorts. The women's pool discreetly tucked away next door had far fewer women and small children in it and most had a full covering of clothes. Do less women know how to swim or feel comfortable in the water? A distinctly holiday feel and changing facilities are provided at both.
Maybe I missed something but the place is not attractive and the man's pool looks well rank. Much better places to go along coast road
If this is your thing, you‚Äôll have a wonderful time. Otherwise, you might be better off staying in bed. It really is a waste of time.

The springs are on the other side of the small peninsula so we took the scooter there. I was really excited but a bit disappointed when we arrived. I had hoped for it to be more than it was. What you get: local bathing spot with shallow ocean water. To end positive, the showers afterwards at Keerimali were veary cheap.

It is quite a long way from Jaffna and also tucked away - do need to ask your way around . Separate ‚Äúponds‚Äù for men and women - but without much background one is unsure what to do . Legend has it that a dip in this pond washes away the ‚Äúcurses‚Äù you have accumulated - but the visit did not inspire . We did  find the ruins of an ancient temple which looked amazing .  On this long journey from Jaffna - please be sure to carry snacks and some packed food specially if you are vegetarian or have diet restrictions . Please ensure your driver has done his prep work well
I didn't go inside, but it looked very interesting to see a hotel spring next to the sea and the water is flowing into the sea. People bathing in the pool making it dirty and tourist unfriendly.
Lots of history behind this place. Most visitors are locals. The surrounding sea area is also beautiful.

Loved it, please tryto go as early as possible to enjoy the beauty and peasfulness.very well maintained. Helpful staff appointment by the local government. I would love if they let families to go together.
This hot springs are with Good blessings when you have a bath according to rituals. There are two sides to ladies and gents . Have faith in the religion and have a bath
This hot spring is known popularly as keerimalai Ambience of the place and facility average .The place is clean

Took the 768 bus from the private bus station in jaffna. Done the hole bus ride to the keerimalai spring. Very sad that the female area is closed at the moment because of repair work. But the bus ride was very interesting and at least there is a nice temple and i saw the ocean.

It's only about 2 km form the jaffna kankasanthurai road. The water is hot and is rite next to the sea. There are 2 springs for men and women separately and cloth changing facilities are available. The water looked very clean. It is a community pool. If you don't mind taking a bath in these pools check it out.

It was a nice warm water pool but the steps are slippery. No one was there when we went. It was a good decision we made to go there. The last bus from there to Jaffna is 5:30pm. You have shops around there and even Tuk's, Tuk's cost 1000 rupees to get to Jaffna. It's a clean place but under constructions, but still you can have a swim. You can watch the sun set when you out from the pool and near the beach. The pool for women are surrounded by huge walls for protection may be. It's a good decision to make, to visit there.
There are two pools that are said to have curative powers. The one for men is good but the one for women not so good. They are open to the sea. Not great for tourists.
if you have time, you can get in, but if there is a crowd it will be noisy. this is not a hot spring per se, but a pool of natural fresh water even though next to the sea.

I would rather call this Keerimalai natural pond/ pool.And this is not a hot spring. .The people around Keerimalai revealed the fact that the tourists come in search of a hot spring which does not exist. This happens more often maybe because of the wrong information which is being displayed on tourist websites.
I would call this a natural pool than Hot Spring. Jaffna weather is hot anyway so very it is very unlikely that you will feel cold spring
This place is neglected & badly maintained. This gives a bad impression of Jaffna. This is a place that needs to be maintained. Not worth a visit until the standards are maintained.
Women‚Äôs section was closed. It looked dirty and not maintained. Sad to see a beautiful bathing spot not maintained.
Loacted opposit to the Naguleshwaran Temple in keeremaley..famous as scared water spring..located very much near to sea. You can have a safe bath too but crowded in weekends.
Popular with the locals, and worth a visit.   Not very inviting for a dip.    poor maintenance to modern standards

A beautiful, clean hot spring next to Naguleswaram Hindu temple. A really nice local/peaceful atmosphere...if I was with friends and had a change of clothes would definitely have had a dip. I would recommend a half day trip to explore Keerimali (including the hot springs) when staying in Jaffna.

Worth a visit if you are in the area. A popular place for the locals to have a dip. Separate swimming pools for males and females. Sunset here provides very good opportunities for the classic tropical sunset photos.
We went there because they were described ad highlights. But well you should see but not sure you should take the bath bearing in mind that there is no water around...,

We visited the baths here with hopes of it being natural springs with a steady flow of water. However, the baths (separate ones for males and females) looked rather dirty and the water looked stagnant (not sure about this). We chose not to go in and swim in the ocean just outside instead. This however also did not happen as it was a Sunday and all the local school boys were in the waters, calling us in (one even threw their sarong at us) and we thought it would be best not to go in. The lady working at the baths however was really sweet and wanted us to have a good time. She even offered to have a male employee chaperone us in the ocean waters but we were exhausted and ready to move on at this point.
Nice experience to have a bath in the sacred pond. The water is mixed with fresh underground water and sea water.

Nothing much in this place, only two somewhat unhygeinic ponds which you can bathe in. However, there is a peice of sea-lagoon I guess still waters where people bathe in as well. Seems there is some hindu religious beleifs here.

The water is not clear and that puts you off a bit. But, you've come all this way so you have to be brace and take the plunge - just don't put your head under water üòÑ it's not a hot spring - just an ocean rick pool

So much was said about the place prior to my visit, i did not find the place all that exiting and appealing. For Hindus its a significant place. As a tourist i found it very unclean and had to think hard before getting into the water. I only put my legs in and came out immediately.
A very interesting place although the aftermath from the civil war are present there and the place should be restored
Clear spring water and I was in a hurry to go back and didnt have to much time to have a swim there!
A kind of place that you will visit but in truth unless you get in what you see in the picture is what it is.
A natural pool right next to the sea, but the water is not salty :) a good place to bathe and swim! remember to take your swim wear

The pools are mixed with spring water from Nilavarai Well which is few miles away and salt water from the seaside. Please note, it is not a hot spring, name on Trip Advisor is misleading.. According to the local, underground tunnel between the pool and the well was naturally formed, and have existed for over 500 years. The local also believe that by soaking in the pool can cure sickness. They seperate the female and male pools. Male pool are much bigger and can be viewed from outside; female pool is covered with tall walls and so it is totally private. When I visited, the female pool was empty. It is free to swim in the pool, but 30 rupees for bathing. No shampoo and shoes are allowed in the pools. I went there early morning at 9am, and was luckily to have a well spoken and friendly lady to show me around the pool. I tested the water, it was considerable warm. The water is clear, but there were some visible rubbish under the pool. There were also many small fishes in the pool. Nice place, great experience if you are able to meet some well spoken local who can tell u stories.

The pools were not looking as nice as I had imagined. Diddnt look inviting. The ladies pool was a disaster. Not used for a long time maybe but if one was to take a dip it would be at a risk to your health!
We found the place crowded and the toilet filthy. We did not swim in the pond. But the beach alongside was nice and the view was good.
It's refreshing to have a bath in the hot springs during any day. Not the ideal place though when it's crowded.

Cost about LKR1000 to get here in a tuk tuk from Jaffna (20km journey) The pools are fed by tidal sea water. The locals are friendly , don't seem to get many tourists. The womans pool is separate, private, and quieter
We did not go into the water, being concerned about hygiene, but a wander around brought in fresh sea air and views of the ocean.
This place is very famous with Tamils and they be live that a bath here will cure some ailments. Situated close to sea
this place is important to see if you are vising Jaffna but need to maintain well. away from the main city Jaffna.
Poorly maintained. If an effort is made to keep the place clean and hygienic, a fee could be charged and would also attract more tourists to the site.
Keerimale Pond opens from 6 am to 6 pm. The outside pool can be seen even during night. Famous place.
The day we visited this place, it was very dirty and it's hard to believe how people actually take a bath from the same. Interesting historical story tho.

The village of Keerimali is located in northern part of the Jaffna Peninsula *.The former it's  name was called 'Tamben-vila', becouse it is near to  Tambapanni city and  the those days it's water is fresh, therefor called 'Tamben-vila', fresh-water pond now called 'Keerimale'. *. It is said that the well is connected to the Keerimale pond where the water has medicinal powers and it is a very ancient place of worship for Hindu's. *.They are believe that's  devotees of Lord Shiva. *. If you want to use the public transport, you can take a  bus from Jaffna it is No: 788 Keerimale-Jaffna Bus.

we had been excited and looking forward to this venture to the 'hot' springs.  First to correct is that they are not Hot springs, our guide told us emphatically they are fresh water or cold springs.  When we arrived we investigated before we parted with the 30 rupees at the changing room.  Anyone can look over the wall and view the pools - separate pools for men and women. The mens pool was basically being used as a swimming pool for the locals, running around dive bombing from the sides and shouting and yelling - not peaceful and tranquil as I had expected! The Ladies pool did not fare much better, we decided not to enter and instead went to lie on the nearby beach which was a much better option.

The beach nearby the springs are by far one of the most inhospitable places I have been to. utter salty water and lime stones that will carve your feet and give you sore marks with bloody legs at the end of the day. You will not see any locals swimming here just the tourist so the locals do know its not a place to go for a swim.
This pond is known as a medicine pond. There's a saying that most of diseases can heal if you had a bath from this pond. But this is a very dirty pond.
i would not enter the water for fear of contracting a fatal illness. it was green with slimy chunks floating around

I used to visit this place as a child, and use the baths... however,   for me it has lost its charm.... so crowed and commercial. but def a beautiful spot and worth a visit. i would not recommend using the baths though.

If you don't mind being an object of curiosity this is an excellent experience. I bathed in the women's section and wore a pair of surf shorts as well as a one piece swimsuit - women were fully clothed, in sarongs, or sari petticoats. There was quite a lot of weed floating about because the pool is fed by the sea. It's an easy ride from Jaffna by minibus   50R. The pool is surrounded by a high wall for privacy. I was the only foreigner.

It has  historical background stories and this pond has connection with  bottomless well in Nilavarai. Even at present, hundreds of locals come and take bath in this pond expecting healing treatment from several disorders.

Dirty looking water. Did not look clean enough to have a bath. Near a beach with huge rocks. Locals said, It was a pretty place before the war. Still need lots of redevelopments to carry out to bring it up to date.

It describes it as a hot springs but it's more outdoor bathing pools. There are separate male and female bathing pools and the male pool is amazing, big stone steps leading down into the pool with a view out over the sea. Had the pool to myself at first which was very relaxing, I don't think it is used all that much on weekdays. It's about an hour by bus from Jaffna, I imagine probably half that time in a tuk tuk or taxi. Keerimalai is nice too with some temples and shrines. Oh and the pool is absolutely free, if you want a shower before/after that's 30 rupees.

It was quite a site to see a freshwater pool next to the ocean. The place looked safe for having a dip. If you do not wish to jump in, you can walk down the steps to touch the water. There is a separate bating area for ladies.
We visited 4 adults and two children. We didn't had a barth. Don't know it's really hot water or how hot it is. Just wash hands to see the difference didn't find any difference.
Due to repair work we could only have a look and imagine how this hot spring really were like. It is beautifully located along the beach side.

We visited as a family, though I had heard it is very dirty, and not advisable to swim here. Still hopeful and curious. However, the surrounds and beach areas also are very dirty, with heaps of rubbish everywhere. A shame to see, especially as it is a sacred site for Hindu funerals. Surely such an area can be kept clean in respect for these ceremonies? Do not advise dipping here!
The male area is under repair and Female area did not look clean at alllll for a bath... But its oki for a visit..
Excellent place to visit with young kids that can swim. Ladies however be cautious. You can't swim in your bikinis.

This well is mostly visited by Hindus who believe in its healing powers. It is a nice shaped ancient construction, well maintained with very clear water. Although it is situated just near the sea, the sea water is salty and the well water is not salty or hot. It comes from an underneath well, that seems to connect this Keerimalai Hot Springs with the Nilavarai bottomless well that is situated 10 km. away from this one.

The Ladies area was open however men's area was closed for renovations. Due to lack of directions, it was difficult to find. Council charges money for development, but need more facilities (cleaner toilets and parking facilities). Pollution along the coast line is (PET bottles and other debris) should be cleaned and educate the residents to avoid pollution. There are a lot more potential to develop this area with many more attractive features and better roads, signs and other infrastructure.

Really nice place and its a miracle according to myths of king Rama.you should have a bath and get the experience of the fresh water springs.but it will be crowded on weekends since the people who come to worship the kovil nearby are using it.

Keerimale pool is not a hot water but a fresh water spring which is a wonder of nature. This water pool right next to the salty Indian Ocean is originated from a natural fresh water spring. The salinity is really less than the levels of sea water.  There are some fictional stories that this pool was a creation of King ‚ÄúRavana‚Äù of Ramayana.  But there were some scientific studies in mid 90‚Äôs about this fresh water spring which is connected to a underground river of Sri Lanka.

we visited  the place on 24/9 and the place was with full with people.the well was separated to 2 as women shold bath seperatly.with lot of people bathing at one time its not a good idea for me to had a bath due to healt reason
A historic place, with a legend. The water is clean and cool. changing facilities are available. best time to visit is early morning before it gets crowded.
If you feel dirty or too warm then you can go to take a bath. Besides that this is not hot spring, water is around 30 degrees and  the place not attractive at all
The Keeramalai water spring is believed to have curing abilities according to the people there. This is just next to the sea and truly is a wonder of nature.
Many believe this is one place you can wash away all your son's committed and refresh and regain life.

Though its unusual to have hot water springs near the sea, this place is badly maintained, though some people bathe here, the water looks very dirty. Needs a big clean up as lots of people visit this place.

The Hot Springs are simply just to tanks whit water right next to the ocean. The water looked really dirty and we definitely did not want to go in the water. To be honest it was just a great waste of time to visit the hot springs.
Its on the things to do in jaffna list.  The water is channelled from the ocean.  There are separate bathing spots for men and women. Worth a look.  Not quite sure about bathing in it though!!
such a nice place to visit but as many have said its not well looked after and was dirty around the area . worth a visit if ya on a tuk tuk tour great temple near by

This is a beautiful place. Unfortunately the place is neglected. There are two bathing pool areas for men and women with ocean water freely flowing in and out. The road leading  to the place is in  bad shape. This could be made into a beautiful  attractive oceanfront tourist resort, if the government takes some interest.in present condition only some local men seem to be using the pools. Needs  a good clean up and improvements to make it an outstanding, tourist site.

After a day sightseeing on our hired scooters, we finally managed to get through all the army blocks to the hot springs. A lot of the roads from Point Pedro are closed so make sure you map out your route and ask your guest house for advice before you leave. The hot springs are actually cold fresh water springs. Men and women bath in separate areas. The men in our group didn't have to pay but we did. It's a very small amount 20rupee. A lovely experience. But don't expect modern or new, this is very old and a genuine experience. Would recommend the visit.

The day we visited the place was full of noisy holiday makers.  So we decided to dip in the Indian Ocean nearby.  The water is warm (as it is anywhere in Jaffna) and the best is the availability of fresh water to refresh (after a sea water bath) at a small fee of LKR 20/-. It is not really hot springs as mentioned.  Located next to a hindu place of worship.  Worth including in a tour of Jaffna.  Early in the morning or late afternoon is recommended to visit due to the scorching sun.

legend has it that ages ago the water here miraculously changed the face of two individuals from some sort of animal face to a human face.. there is a picture depicting this story in a building right next to the springs. So far no other miracles have been reported. There are 2 springs one for men & 1 for women. Although supposed to be sacred there were a bunch of kids having a  super time in there. The female one looked dirty. Apparently the water here somehow empties out to the sea each day and refills from the springs below...

Not sure where the name comes from. This is basically a bathing area that is fed by the sea water. They separate the bathing areas for men and women, with the bathing area for the women being enclosed by a tall wall. Its interesting, but I was actually expecting hot springs so this was a bit of a letdown. The water was clean, refreshing, and great on a warm day. But in the women's bathing area there are kids, and the sound of their screaming and laughing was bouncing off the walls and made it rather unpleasant.

Nothing special really, but: - There is no much you can do nearby Jaffna - A tour to springs is interesting in itself as you explore the peninsula on the way and see how its changing after the civil war - If coupled with a few places in the area makes an interesting day trip - Definitely non-touristy - mostly locals there, so that is quite nice, you get an opportunity to have a glimpse of real Sri Lanka
Mens' bath is interesting, but the ladies' was said to be good.  The photo exhibition in the hall nearby is worth a look.

Actually getting there was half the fun. The trip takes us to the country side and exposed us to the rural side of Jaffna.  The temple complex is right by the ocean and presented an interesting combination of old and new Hindu temples.  There were many young man enjoying the swim on the men‚Äôs pool, but not a single woman on their side.   This is a recommend trip to get a feel for what the most northern end of Sri Lanka is like.

I'd planned on taking a dip in the springs, which aren't hot, but warmish because they're heated by the sun. As other reviewers have noted, they are basically two segregated swimming pools, the men's at least made of local rock. The pool is small, but looks fine, inviting even, apart from men in the pool who were clearing their nasal passages and spitting into the water. It happened regularly, and no one seemed to mind. I did, and gave it a miss.

This is situated at Keerimalai which is about 17 KM from Jaffna town presently the road was very well done and you can reach within 30 minutes ( Jaffna KKS road) There are ample public transport available. It is very close to Kankeasathurai Railway station. Basically it is a hot spring (Luke warm water) situated very close to the Naguleswaram Temple (Hindu Shiva Temple) There are several believes and myths about this Springs Once a saint who had a Mongoose face had got his human face after having bath here and it is believed that having a bath at this place will wash all your sins off. This is situated adjoining to the sea if the climate is good you can have a sea bath also. After having bath you can go the Shiva temple. There are two wells situated next to each other and separated by a wall one for men and other foe women you have some privacy. There are changing rooms with bathing facilities provided here for a fee but those are not clean at all. Regarding the well you must be watch full because they are slippery. This is a nice place but very badly maintained. There are no entry fee. I am told it will get crowded when time goes if you want a clean and smooth bathing better you go early in the morning (like 6 am)

These are two cement tanks. One for men and one for women. The water is lukewarm. The changing rooms are filthy and nightmarish. Far too many noisy kids screeching and running around in their underwear. A dip in the sea behind this spot is much more interesting. The water outlet canal from these tanks is also directed to the sea there.

It is well maintained by the local body. However the pool should have a shower fitted so that most bathers and douse themselves before jumping to the pool. This is important as many pilgrims arrive from distances and it would ensure considerations from a health point of view as it is a community pool.

Keerimalai Shiva Temple is one of my regular visiting places whenever I travel to Jaffna.It is because as Hindus we have some duties to fulfil at this temple for our dead blood relatives.There has been tremendous improvements that have been made during the past few years.The temple refurbishment work is in progress. The road leading from maviddapuram kantha swamy kovil to keerimalai is now tarred and makes travel more comfortable.The temple itself has historical importance for Hindus which is also called Nahuleswaram. It gives you immense happiness and peace to pray at this temple.We travelled by a three wheeler to this destination from Jaffna Town.

We caught a local bus there and back from Jaffna which was half the fun. 40 minutes crammed in with locals going past markets and temples on our way. The Springs have been made into a swimming pool with a open Mens area and a walled in Womans area. It is only waist high and the bottom is large boulders with some sandy patches. It was not a hot spring but more a salt water pool at normal temperature. Don't make a sepcial visit but id you do have extra time in Jaffna and feel the need to get out of the city this will do the trick.

This is an experience that you must try when visiting Jaffna, the water coming into the springs is to this day still unknown where it comes from which is what makes it special! (Be careful when getting into the water as the rocks are slippery.)
This is a religious place and hot water springs... supposed to be with healing powers for those with belief....so it is not a touristic place

Visited the place on our way to Point Pedro. The entrance to the Women's section did not look too welcoming. In spite of instructions that soap should not be used we saw a little girl happily soaping herself - while her Mum looked on. The spelling on the Notice Board has to be rectified - re "Fealty" words.

We visited Keerimalai (which apparently translates from Tamil to Mongoose Mountain according to my Dad!) early on a Sunday morning - it was baking hot so a dip in the spring was very welcomed. The area for men to bathe is very nice with a view of the sea. The area for women, whilst the water was still nice, had tall walls around it and was less scenic. We were the first women to arrive so we had the spring to ourselves! It would have been nice if we could have bathed in the men's area as well though! It was free to bathe in the pool and 20rs to use the fresh water showers. Definitely a must see of northern Sri Lanka!

It was a fabulous experience to have a hot water bath at Keerimalai Hot Springs. There after we jumped in to keeramalai beach too. Wash room for fresh water baths available on site with excellent toilets and changing rooms.

A swim in the sacred pond having healing powers... I was lucky to be one of the people who have been here, more so ever I had gone there on a weekday so there weren't many people,  I really enjoyed swimming in the pond, the water too was slightly warm and felt very pure and fresh,  I came out only after 1 hour,  that too because I would have missed the bus back to Jaffna!!

The waters here are said to be therapeutic. The baths are  of historic and religious importance to believers.  Hence a "must visit" place . This is a great place to observe social interactions and religious observances amongst the people of Jaffna and others who visit here. There are separate baths for men and women . Had I been prepared, I would have liked to try it -- shall do so on my next visit. There are special days in July and February which are considered to be auspicious for a healing dip. The baths would be particularly colorful on such occasions.

This spring is an excellent stop if your in Jaffna. The spring is split into male and female areas with the latter being enclosed behind a wall. For men, a dip in the male spring is a fantastic experience. The locals with no doubt have a chat with you and the water is a great temperature and the whole pool itself is in a nice setting.
The young men and women had their own part  of the building , easy access to the beach area. Interesting to mingle with the friendly locals.

We visited during a hot day, so the cool water was appreciated. I always find these temple baths, green, slimy and floating with plastic bottles. Although it was a little bit slimy and green, it was clean and full of locals up for a chat or swimming race. The water is supposed to be spring fed, but I think there is a large content of ocean water. I'm still waiting for my religious epiphany from my dip, but it certainly cooled my body temperature. There did not appear to be change rooms, but there is a changing alcove that is respected by every bather. Ladies, you can watch, but not stare, you have your own pool. Women only, so I can't tell you any more.

This pond is said to have medicinal/healing properties, even said to make barren women become fertile. So it is a ritual for most people who visit Jaffna. But if your just a tourist then it may not be worth the effort. It tends to get quite crowded. Separate area for women.

The local tour guide told us that the pool was fresh water, but having swum there this is not the case.    Once again it was not hard to pick the non local in the pool, and with 100 or so local school children watching, was entertaining.  The near by temple also worth a look too.
